title.value: Intra-Host Evolution Analyses in an Immunosuppressed Patient Supports SARS-CoV-2 Viral Reservoir Hypothesis
title.justification: The title is explicitly mentioned at the top of the first page of the research paper.
title.quote: Intra-Host Evolution Analyses in an Immunosuppressed Patient Supports SARS-CoV-2 Viral Reservoir Hypothesis

extractions.description: The paper explores the intra-host evolution of SARS-CoV-2 in an immunosuppressed patient, providing evidence for the viral reservoir hypothesis. It analyzes the genetic events and mutations that occurred. This study highlights the presence of distinct viral populations in the patient, suggesting the emergence of immune escape variants and a potential ability of the virus to reinfect anatomical locations, not originally sampled, contributing to prolonged infection cases.

type.justification: The study involves experimental analysis and observation of SARS-CoV-2 mutations and viral populations within a patient, indicating it is empirical research.
type.quote: Here, we present the case of an immunosuppressed patient that developed distinct populations with immune escape mutations throughout the course of their infection.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on analyzing viral genetic sequences and mutations, which fits into the Viral Genomics field.
name.quote: Keywords: SARS-CoV-2; immune escape mutations; viral genomics; phylogenetics

name.justification: The paper uses phylogenetic analysis to study viral evolution, which is a core aspect of phylogenetics.
name.quote: phylogenetic and intra-host single nucleotide variant (iSNV) analysis of viral sequences, we found several viral populations containing immune escape mutations

name.justification: The study of immune escape mutations and immune response in the patient contributes to the field of immunology.
name.quote: mutations were acquired without the patient being treated with mAbs nor convalescent sera and without them developing a detectable immune response

name.justification: The paper mentions the use of SARS-CoV-2 sequences from the LSPQ database, making it relevant as a dataset used in the study.
name.quote: SARS-CoV-2 consensus sequence data were obtained from the LSPQ database through the CoVSeQ consortium

aliases: Laboratoire de Santé Publique du Québec database

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper does not explicitly reference a specific title for this dataset, it is described within the methods section.
referenced_paper_title.quote: SARS-CoV-2 consensus sequence data were obtained from the LSPQ database through the CoVSeQ consortium: https://covseq.ca (accessed on 16 November 2021).

name.justification: The paper uses datasets from NCBI's Sequence Read Archive for analysis.
name.quote: Serial sequences from two patients described by Lee et al. [10] (P1 and P2) were obtained from NCBI’s Sequence Read Archive (study SRP357108).

referenced_paper_title.justification: The specific dataset used is identified as part of a broader collection under NCBI's Sequence Read Archive.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Serial sequences from two patients described by Lee et al. [10] (P1 and P2) were obtained from NCBI’s Sequence Read Archive (study SRP357108).

name.justification: GenPipes is mentioned as the framework used for producing variant calls and consensus sequences in the paper's methods section.
name.quote: All LSPQ sequencing data were analyzed using the GenPipes [21] Covseq pipelines to produce variant calls and consensus sequences.

referenced_paper_title.value: GenPipes: An open-source framework for distributed and scalable genomic analyses
referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference paper provides detailed information on GenPipes, making it relevant.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Bourgey, M.; Dali, R.; Eveleigh, R.; Chen, K.C.; Letourneau, L.; Fillon, J.; Michaud, M.; Caron, M.; Sandoval, J.; Lefebvre, F.; et al. GenPipes: An open-source framework for distributed and scalable genomic analyses. GigaScience 2019, 8, giz037.
